title: List of painted churches in Cyprus
text:
There are over sixty <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20church%20architecture">churches</a> in <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> with <a href="Byzantine%20art">Byzantine</a> and post-Byzantine <a href="Mural">wall paintings</a>. Of these, ten that are situated in the <a href="Troodos%20Mountains">Troodos Mountains</a> have been inscribed jointly on the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20List">World Heritage List</a> as the <a href="Painted%20Churches%20in%20the%20Tro%C3%B6dos%20Region">Painted Churches in the Troodos Region</a>.
History.
The origins of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> on the island may be traced to the visit of <a href="Paul%20the%20Apostle">St. Paul</a>, <a href="Barnabas">St. Barnabas</a> and <a href="Mark%20the%20Evangelist">St. Mark</a> around AD 46. After the <a href="Fall%20of%20the%20Western%20Roman%20Empire">fall</a> of the western Roman Empire, Cyprus came under the sway of <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantium</a>, although the timely discovery of Barnabas' <a href="relics">relics</a> helped the <a href="Church%20of%20Cyprus">Church of Cyprus</a> uphold its <a href="autocephaly">autocephaly</a>. The crusader <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Cyprus">Kingdom of Cyprus</a> outlived the <a href="Fall%20of%20Constantinople">Fall of Constantinople</a> by a generation; the subsequent <a href="Catherine%20Cornaro">sale</a> of the island to <a href="Republic%20of%20Venice">Venice</a> led to a brief period of <a href="Italo-Byzantine">Italo-Byzantine</a> painting. In 1571 Cyprus <a href="Ottoman%20Cyprus">fell to the Ottomans</a> and the practice of ecclesiastic wall painting largely came to an end.
Organization of space.
Subject to the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20church%20architecture">layout</a> of each church, the <a href="Iconography%23Christian%20iconography">iconographic</a> schema typically accords with the classic Byzantine , evident also in <a href="Byzantine%20mosaic">Byzantine mosaic decoration</a>, the three zones comprising: (1) the <a href="dome">dome</a> and <a href="Semi-dome">conch</a> of the <a href="apse">apse</a>; (2) the <a href="pendentive">pendentive</a>s, <a href="squinches">squinches</a> and upper <a href="Vault%20%28architecture%29">vaults</a>; and (3) the lower, secondary vaults and walls. The first is reserved for depictions of the holiest persons, the <a href="Christ%20Pantocrator">Christ Pantokrator</a> and the <a href="Madonna%20%28art%29">Virgin</a>; the second for scenes from the <a href="Life%20of%20Christ%20in%20art">Life of Christ</a> and the <a href="Great%20Feasts%20of%20the%20Orthodox%20Church">festival cycle</a>; and the third for the choir of <a href="Intercession%20of%20saints">intercessory</a> <a href="Saint%23Eastern%20Orthodoxy">saints</a>.
Preservation.
Since the <a href="Turkish%20invasion%20of%20Cyprus">Turkish invasion of Cyprus</a> in 1974, a number of churches in the <a href="Northern%20Cyprus">north</a> have been <a href="Looted%20art">looted</a> and their wall paintings <a href="Detachment%20of%20wall%20paintings">detached</a> to supply the international <a href="antiquities%20trade">antiquities trade</a>. Among them is the <a href="Church%20of%20Saint%20Evphemianos%2C%20Lysi">Church of St. Evphemianos</a> in <a href="Lysi">Lysi</a>: the thirteenth-century <a href="Christ%20Pantocrator">Christ Pantocrator</a> mural and surrounding angels were detached, leaving their feet behind; the paintings were then acquired for the <a href="Menil%20Collection">Menil Collection</a> and displayed at the <a href="Byzantine%20Fresco%20Chapel">Byzantine Fresco Chapel</a> in <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston, Texas</a> before their <a href="Art%20repatriation">repatriation</a> to the south in 2012. Meanwhile, many churches in the south been the subject of <a href="Conservation-restoration">conservation</a> interventions, conducted by the Department of Antiquities, <a href="Dumbarton%20Oaks%23Institutional%20Program">Dumbarton Oaks</a> and the <a href="Courtauld%20Institute%20of%20Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a>, aimed at reconciling the competing demands of stability, legibility and authenticity within the framework of ongoing devotional practice.
